I don't think any of the coefficients have to be integers.  It is just most common that they are given as integers.  In fact, there are some applications where you might opt to specifically make C=1, in which case A and B have to be something other than an integer to make it work.

It is a line because there are only two variables of the space where it takes place, and it is a linear relationship between the two of them.  Since no z-term is given, it doesn't take place in 3-dimensional space, but only in a single plane.  C may look like it is a variable, but it is a constant in this particular context.  Usually, the early lettters in the alphabet are used as constants, and the letters at the end of the alphabet are used as variables (either spatial dimension variables specifically, or variables in general that don't necessarily stand for anything).  BlackPenRedPen has a video on the Mathematician's alphabet, going over what the letters most commonly stand for in mathematics.  You can rearrange this format, and find the y=m*x+b form of this line.  Note that my little b is not necessarily equal to your big B.  You will get, y= (-A/B)*x - C/B, which means m=-A/B, and b = -C/B
